node.title: Cannes winner Titane is a surreal horror about a serial killer with a sexual fetish for cars
node.alt: A woman in fishnets and gold bikini strikes a pose on the bonnet of a car painted with flames
node.description: For all its body-horror and swoon-inducing gore,Â Titane is a multifaceted exploration of identity and belonging.
node.content:
["Extreme violence and tenderness intertwine in French filmmaker Julia Ducournau's stylish and brutal Cannes Palme d'Or winner Titane \u2013 a frenetic and surreal body horror movie.", "Agathe Rousselle plays Alexia, a serial killer with a sexual fetish for cars who evades police by adopting the identity of a missing boy.", "Her mechanophilia is foreshadowed in the film's prologue \u2013 a road accident in childhood that leaves her with a titanium plate embedded in her skull \u2014 but her bloodlust is harder to pin down.", "", "
Ducournau became the second female director (after Jane Campion) to win the Palme d'Or when Titane premiered at the 2021 Cannes Film Festival.(Supplied: Neon/Carole Bethuel)
", "Perhaps not since Claire Denis's 2001 vampire allegory Trouble Every Day has a director been so invested in the perspective of a female predator, and so resistant to easy psychological explanations. Ducournau's impressive 2007 debut, Raw, dealt with similar themes, depicting a young vegetarian who discovers insatiable cannibal appetites. It was also an improbably delicate and surprisingly insightful coming of age story.", "Titane is a much more complex film \u2013 and more ambitious \u2014 moving on from the concerns of young adulthood to the anxieties of parenthood and family, while parsing themes of gender and body transformation.", "The first murder we see Alexia commit is deceptively straightforward, like an act of vengeance in a rape-revenge movie. It occurs at an auto show where the camera picks her out in a crowded convention hall gyrating suggestively on the bonnet of a car to pounding music. Bouncers warn the mostly male punters that they can look but they can't touch, but it's not enough to dissuade one pest, who lives to regret it.", "As vicious as it is, the gory encounter inspires qualified sympathy for Alexia as a woman reacting to a sexual assault; but a bloodier scene later in the film is harder to watch.", "After a steamy date turns sour, she slashes and pummels her way through the occupants of a share house \u2013 unprovoked and without real justification \u2014 while Ducournau doubles down with the ironic soundtrack choice of Italian pop singer Caterina Caselli's 60s hit Nessuno mi pu\u00f2 giudicare ('No one can judge me').", "", "
\u201cI feel that my film talks about humanity very much ... It\u2019s the\u00a0only\u00a0thing it talks about,\"\u00a0Ducournau told The Guardian.(Supplied: Neon/Carole Bethuel)
", "Lurking here is an obvious challenge to the audience to reassess our preconceptions of women and violence, but the film's true ambitions only become apparent when things stop going Alexia's way and she can't kill like she used to.", "It begins with a pregnancy, or something like it.", "The conception takes place during an encounter with a muscle car \u2014 a fantasy sequence that recalls David Cronenberg's eroticised depictions of flesh and metal in his sadomasochistic tour de force Crash.", "Alexia is left with a persistent black discharge that resembles motor oil and a metallic carapace growing underneath her belly's skin.", "Her subsequent loss of physical control is then exacerbated when she meets Vincent (Vincent Lindon), a fire station chief with a missing son.", "", "
Ducournau wrote the role of Vincent for Lindon (The Measure of a Man), who did two years of weight training to prepare for the part.(Supplied: Neon/Carole Bethuel)
", "It's a relationship born out of desperation.", "On the run from police, Alexia sees a missing persons billboard and makes a split-second decision to pass herself off as Vincent's child.", "She performs improvised cosmetic surgery on herself by smashing her chiselled face against the basin of a public toilet and hands herself in.", "Vincent doesn't seem to need too much convincing.", "The patience and warmth he shows her are a stark contrast to Alexia's distant and scornful biological father (a doctor, like Ducournau's real-life parents).", "He wants to believe she is his boy, and doesn't question her silence, or reluctance to embrace him.", "", "
\"When I saw Agathe [Rousselle] for the first time at a casting session, she really stood out. She had the right physique and a fascinating face, but also a presence,\" Ducournau said in the press notes.(Supplied: Neon/Carole Bethuel)
", "In the narrative haze between realism and fantasy, Lindon's masterfully shaded performance lends credibility to the desperate scenario, allowing Ducournau to steer her film away from its early focus on sexual desire, towards a multifaceted exploration of identity and belonging.", "Alexia ends up living at the station \u2014 a compound where a dozen or so men live under Vincent's command \u2014 and she's issued with a fireman's uniform and hat.", "It's a charade, but no one seems game to tell Vincent.", "Ducournau is sympathetic to his loneliness, exacerbated by the solitude of his rank and the age gap between him and his men. She photographs his muscular body naked, revealing his sagging buttocks covered in small bruises where he injects himself daily with steroids. He can't stop the advance of time, but he tries all the same, and yells his frustration when his body gives out during exercise routines.", "Meanwhile, Alexia becomes a prisoner in her own web of deceit and denial. We get tormented scenes in mirrors where she's strapping down her breasts and picking away at the skin from her bulging belly.", "The body \u2013 once her weapon \u2014 becomes her enemy.", "In contrast to the freedom of the film's first half \u2013 where she strides through the world confident in her ability to dominate others physically and emotionally \u2013 the second half of the film becomes a cloistered drama.", "The building is both haven and prison \u2013 a concrete box with a pink tiled bathroom and family meals cooked for two.", "", "
Ducournau is a horror afficionado and told The Guardian that Hitchcock's Vertigo was a big reference point for Titane.(Supplied: Neon/Carole Bethuel)
", "Does Alexia have the stamina for this unrelenting performance of domesticity and duty?", "The question's urgency waxes and wanes with the film's uneven pacing, but there are moments when the conceit finds its friction point.", "During an all-male office disco, for example, Alexia's muscle memory betrays her and she busts out some old dance moves atop a fire engine, sending jaws to the floor.", "The misstep reinvigorates the film's curiosity about the nature of gender identity.", "But the pressing issue of Alexia's mechanical womb, Ducournau's most obvious body horror idea, is what drags the drama to its watershed finale. Too soon, it seems, given how many ideas feel undercooked.", "Perhaps that's unfair, given how far reaching Ducournau's scrutiny of gender, identity, family and parenthood is. But there's a slightly perfunctory feeling to the film's finale, and the way Alexia finishes up as less of an emotional being and more of a symbolic one, receding in the film's rear-view mirror.", "Titane is in cinemas now."]
